channel.title: BBC Sport

item.title: The big questions now Scotland are going to the World Cup
item.description: Where are we going? What's the score with visas & ESTAs? Who will sing our World Cup song?

item.title: Football not part of government ticket crackdown
item.description: The government has announced legislation to outlaw the sale of tickets to sports events at inflated prices - but it will not cover football.

item.title: After Scotland qualify for World Cup, what happens now?
item.description: Scotland have qualified for the 2026 World Cup, but what happens now?

item.title: Glasgow City suffer extra-time loss to Sporting
item.description: Sporting Club score two extra-time goals for a 4-2 aggregate win, ending Glasgow City's Europa Cup run in Lisbon.

item.title: Liverpool only January option for Guehi - Thursday's gossip
item.description: Crystal Palace view Liverpool as the only viable suitor for Marc Guehi, Manchester United and Inter Milan battle over Karim Adeyemi, and Ivan Toney is ready to take a huge pay cut to secure a Premier League return.

item.title: Why are Man Utd not playing on a Saturday for two months?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything explains why Manchester United are not playing on a Saturday for two months

item.title: Referee coach denies 'man-handling' WSL official
item.description: A referee coach has denied "manhandling" Women's Super League referee Lisa Benn after she told an employment tribunal that he "forcefully pushed" her during a match.

item.title: Non-league club bans 'micro' shin pads after 'unbearable' injury to forward
item.description: Non-league Ilfracombe Town ban 'micro' shin pads after forward Riley Martin suffered an "unbearable" double-leg break in a South West Peninsula League match at the weekend.

item.title: Scotland edge out Denmark in six-goal epic to reach World Cup
item.description: Watch the best of the action as Scotland beat Denmark 4-2 to reach the men's World Cup finals for the first time since 1998.

item.title: Does Solskjaer deserve more respect for his time managing Man Utd?
item.description: Does Ole Gunnar Solskjaer deserve more respect for his time as Manchester United manager? BBC Sport's Simon Stone takes a closer look at his reign.

item.title: Wales will 'take anybody' in World Cup play-off draw
item.description: A closer look at Wales' possible World Cup play-off semi-final opponents as former striker Rob Earnshaw says a tie with Republic of Ireland would be "incredible".

item.title: McClaren quits as Jamaica manager
item.description: Eighteen years after being sacked as England manager, Steve McClaren resigns as Jamaica boss following their failure to qualify automatically for the World Cup.

item.title: Suspended sentence for Norway's Schjelderup after sharing illegal video
item.description: Norway international Andreas Schjelderup has been given a two-week suspended prison sentence after a Danish court found him guilty of sharing sexual material of two boys under the age of 18.

item.title: Australia cap Hughes called up by Wales
item.description: Wales call up Melbourne City midfielder Laura Hughes, who has been capped by Australia, for their international camp in Spain.

item.title: Was McTominay overhead kick not even Scotland's best goal of the night?
item.description: Scotland scored three stunning goals in their era-defining win over Denmark - but which was the best?

item.title: Curacao become smallest nation to qualify for World Cup
item.description: Curacao have become the smallest nation to qualify for the World Cup after drawing with Steve McClaren's Jamaica.

item.title: Boro set to appoint Hellberg as head coach
item.description: Middlesbrough are set to appoint Hammarby head coach Kim Hellberg as the successor to Rob Edwards.

item.title: 'It's not about getting credit' - Solskjaer reflects on time at Man Utd
item.description: Speaking to BBC Sport's Kelly Somers, former Manchester United manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer reflects on his time in charge at Old Trafford, insisting he "enjoyed" the pressure placed upon him while he was in the role.

item.title: 'I'm the USA coach!' - Pochettino upset by reporter's question
item.description: Watch as USA head coach Mauricio Pochettino reacts angrily to a reporter's question following his side's 5-1 friendly win against Uruguay.

item.title: McLean nets from halfway in stoppage time to seal Scotland's World Cup spot
item.description: Kenny McLean scores from the halfway line, deep into stoppage time, to seal Scotland's first men's World Cup appearance since 1998 as they beat Denmark 4-2.

item.title: Have fun and enjoy it - Russo's advice to young footballers
item.description: England and Arsenal forward Alessia Russo is interviewed by Lionesses fan Isavella and passes on advice to her and other young footballers.

item.title: Flying? Floundering? Failing? How would your club's report card read?
item.description: Our Premier League fan writers give their verdict on your club's season so far.

item.title: Hakimi and Chebbak named African players of the year
item.description: Achraf Hakimi and Ghizlane Chebbak deliver a double success for Morocco as they are named 2025 African men's and women's footballer of the year respectively.

item.title: Haiti reach World Cup despite coach having never been to the country
item.description: Haiti coach Sebastien Migne guides the country to their second World Cup, despite having never been able to visit the country.

item.title: Is Clarke now Scotland's greatest manager?
item.description: Steve Clarke cements his place in Scottish football folklore by leading his nation to three major tournaments.

item.title: 'Sir Steve', tears and greatest night of lives - what Scotland fans said
item.description: Scotland fans give their reactions to the 4-2 over Denmark that secures a place at the World Cup finals for Steve Clarke's side.

item.title: Captain Salah and leave out Haaland? FPL team of the week
item.description: With a tough away game at Newcastle for FPL top scorer Erling Haaland, gameweek 12 presents a chance to give the captain's armband to someone else - and that man is Mohamed Salah.

item.title: Exeter v Burton postponed after stadium fire
item.description: Exeter City's League One game with Burton Albion on Saturday is postponed after a fire at their St James Park ground.

item.title: Arsenal to end sponsorship deal with Visit Rwanda
item.description: Arsenal announce the club will end their eight-year sponsorship deal with Visit Rwanda at the conclusion of the 2025-26 season.

item.title: The non-league striker proving a match for Haaland
item.description: A Merthyr Town striker is proving more than a match for Erling Haaland with his impressive goal-scoring form.

item.title: The Champions League goalkeeper studying to be a doctor
item.description: Goalkeeper Carina Schluter is splitting her time between sitting in lecture theatres and playing in the Women's Champions League with St Polten.

item.title: Who has qualified for World Cup and when is draw?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explore when the World Cup draw is, how the seeding works and who has qualified so far.

item.title: How has world changed since Scotland were last at men's finals?
item.description: When Scotland last reached a men's World Cup, the Scottish parliament didn't exist, Google wasn't a thing and a pint of lager was roughly Â£1.90.

item.title: 'Close to perfect' - Bellamy revels in Wales masterclass
item.description: Craig Bellamy says Wales' 7-1 thrashing of North Macedonia - which secured a home World Cup play-off semi-final - was "close to perfect".

item.title: 'Now feels like the right time to start family'
item.description: Northern Ireland captain and Birmingham City striker Simone Magill says she has "felt the love" after announcing her pregnancy.

item.title: 'I always have a point to prove' - Wales' Johnson
item.description: Spurs forward Brennan Johnson says he is often "tough on himself" after he shone for Wales in their 7-1 World Cup qualifying win against North Macedonia.

item.title: Who is not going to the 2026 World Cup?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team looks at which countries and players will not be competing at the 2026 World Cup

item.title: I couldn't get Jota out of my head today - Robertson
item.description: Scotland's players talk, and talk, and talk after sealing a place in the men's World Cup for the first time since 1998 with a scarcely believable 4-2 victory over Denmark.

item.title: Norwich name ex-Rangers boss Clement as head coach
item.description: Norwich City appoint former Rangers manager Philippe Clement as head coach on a contract that runs until 2029.

item.title: 'Quite cute' and 'in sync' - the father-son duo in non-league dugout
item.description: Father-son duo Craig and Scott Laird on the unique experience of co-managing together in the dugout at non-league side Street FC.

item.title: Which Premier League teams will lose most players to Afcon?
item.description: BBC Sport has a look at which Premier League clubs will be most - and least - affected by the Africa Cup of Nations.

item.title: The key questions facing Tuchel before World Cup
item.description: England head coach Thomas Tuchel now faces key decisions in the countdown to the World Cup, says chief football writer Phil McNulty.

item.title: Is Bellingham Tuchel's best player or problem to solve?
item.description: BBC Sport explores Jude Bellingham and Thomas Tuchel's latest dispute and what it means moving forward.

item.title: Target Liverpool, go four at back - FPL tips to kick-start your season
item.description: What have we learned so far this FPL season? What's the best way to approach the game? Our four experts give you their best advice to get ahead of your rivals.

item.title: From Spurs fringes to Dutch delight - Parrott's rise to Irish hero
item.description: With five goals in two huge wins over Portugal and Hungary that have propelled Republic of Ireland into the World Cup play-offs, it has been a dream international window for Troy Parrott.

item.title: Meet the man who played in two games, in two countries... in one day
item.description: BBC Sport tells the story of Soren Lerby, who once played for Denmark and Bayern Munich on the same day - in different countries.

item.title: Transfers - September to December 2025
item.description: Check out the significant signings and departures in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, EFL and Women's Super League.

item.title: Manager ins and outs - 2025-26 season
item.description: BBC Sport tracks all the manager ins and outs in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, Women's Super League, English Football League and National League.

item.title: What is Scotland's World Cup record?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team look at how Scotland have fared in previous World Cup competitions.

item.title: Why are England called the Three Lions?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain where the three lions on the England shirt came from.

item.title: Why VAR gets involved in some penalties but not others
item.description: It was a weekend of VAR penalty decisions in the Premier League, with spot-kicks awarded, cancelled and ignored. BBC Sport explains why.

item.title: Why can Channel Islands players play for England?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team look at why players born in the Channel Islands like Alex Scott can represent England at a senior level.

item.title: Why do footballers tape up their wrists?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explains why footballers use tape to wrap their wrists.

item.title: 'I woke up this morning with no nerves' - Clarke hails Scotland players
item.description: Head coach Steve Clarke hails his Scotland players after they qualify for a first men's World Cup since 1998.

item.title: How content creator became scout in Serie A
item.description: How former content creator Felix Johnston became a first-team scout for Serie A club Como 1907.

item.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
item.description: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

item.title: From farming village to Liverpool icon - the Salah story
item.description: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

item.title: Napoli 'smell blood' & target Premier League's discarded stars
item.description: After Scott McTominay was a hit, Napoli went back to the Premier League for Kevin de Bruyne, could more players follow them to Serie A?

item.title: How does Daniel Levy run Tottenham - and would he ever leave?
item.description: With Tottenham struggling on the pitch and chairman Daniel Levy facing criticism from fans, BBC Sport looks at how the club is run and what the future might hold.

item.title: When River Plate icon Diaz took over fourth-tier Oxford
item.description: Twenty years on from Ramon Diaz's surprising appointment at Oxford United, BBC Sport looks at what happened and how it went.

item.title: East meets west London - the mentor who changed Chelsea
item.description: Vinay Menon knew nothing about football when he went for a meeting at a west London mansion in 2009. A few weeks later he was in the heart of the Chelsea dressing room.

item.title: The air crash and the underdogs - a triumph for a lost generation
item.description: Nineteen years and 10 miles separated Zambia's football team from a lost, golden generation on a fateful night in Libreville.
